Topic.Title: Want a reason why AMD is UP, hold down the shift key and type ps4. Did you get PS$? lol

Message.Msg: I don't think that they are going to die immediately, but it's easy to see their decline. Most of my game playing is casual, and I do it on a medium size tablet, followed by a phone. Serious games are played solo on a PC+GPU system, and family games are played on a Wii. When I'm serious, I want the full experience. I don't want to play a beautiful game on hardware that doesn't provide the whole experience. Consoles were great when they were the best experience, or an equivalent experience. But once it was clear that PC+GPU systems were better, most of the appeal of the console went away. Paying full price for a game, knowing that I'm only seeing part of it, doesn't sit well with me. And I think I'm pretty typical in that respect. The next generation of consoles are lining up to be pretty much a mid-range PC. And if the past is any indication, they'll stay with that configuration for at least five years. So from day one it's easy to buy better hardware, and by year two you know you'll be missing part of the experience of new titles. Console makers are hoping that consumers won't notice that they are getting essentially a repackaged, limited capability PC. But this is a market that is smart. Part of it lives and breathes this stuff. They make up their draft Christmas list in July, after six months of research. And tell all of their friends what to buy. Nvidia could have fought to retain the console business. But they already know it would be a low value business. They only get a tiny slice of the zero-margin hardware revenue, not a chunk of the profitable game content business which is where the money is made. And the business might not have last generation's volume. AMD, on the other hand, is in a different position. Since they have a CPU, they can deliver the whole hardware solution and get a much bigger slice of the hardware revenue. Plus they might get to make the chips, reducing their penalty payments to GF for not using capacity.

Topic.Title: Intc. New chips mobile and tablet

Message.Msg: Mars, the bottom line is can Intel effectively compete in a longtime ARM dominated sector on pricing with their costly massive infrastructure? Why would customers jump to Intel when they have been longtime acclimated to ARM, pricing, and performance. Intel is still lacking in the gpu area and always will. If Intel plans on competing with a "good enough" gpu performance, then ARM should be able to keep their dominance with "good enough" overall performance. Asking people to jump ship just because it's Intel is not going to cut it.

Topic.Title: Intc. New chips mobile and tablet

Message.Msg: How "new" is it really? - Silvermont or Airmont, it remains basically an ATOM. Below are comments from analyst Doug Freeman of RBC Capital:: "...We believe there is still a lot of skepticism in the marketplace despite the company’s ability to illustrate favorable benchmarks as the company attempts to change its perception vs. ARM. The vast end-markets that Silvermont services, suggests that Intel is giving customers increased flexibility of where to deploy Atom-cores. While we are encouraged by the Atom roadmap, we believe the market will take a ‘wait and see’ approach as Intel attempts to establish more serious in-roads in ARM-dominated markets. SOURCE: Barrons today PS: Silvermont: 22nm; Airmont: 14nm.

Topic.Title: Intc. New chips mobile and tablet

Message.Msg: Customers are jumping to Intel at the rate of one phone design a month ever since Medfield was announced and that rate should only accelerate with Clovertrail+ and Merrifield. Intel does not price its mobile chips expensively as they end up in competitively priced designs. They are also enabling new players some of which are just using the standard intel reference design. Medfield/Clovertrail are good designs, they give similar performance/power to Apple A6 and slightly better performance/power than Qualcomm Snapdragon designs. Silvermont will take this equal/slight advantage and make it a big advantage making it hard to ignore by big traditional ARM OEMs as customers will eventually be picking the winners. Apple will still be using its own ARM chips and the cheap $10 Chinese chips will still survive but everyone else using ARM faces severe competition which will reduce their prices. Silvermont's gpu is a cut down version of Haswell's.

Topic.Title: Intc. New chips mobile and tablet

Message.Msg: Concluding remarks from an Anandtech article on Silvermont. SOURCE: Anandtech Final Words Silvermont really is Intel’s Conroe for the mobile market, but not in the sense that many have been expecting. Given that success in mobile is so closely tied to device wins, Silvermont alone isn’t enough. Unlike Conroe, a very competitive Silvermont won’t change the world overnight. What Silvermont does however is offer a great foundation for Intel going forward. Conroe lead to Penryn, Nehalem, Westmere, Sandy Bridge, Ivy Bridge and soon, Haswell. It was the platform that Intel could build on regularly by executing on tick-tock. Conroe paved the way for the insane advantage Intel has held onto for the past few years. Silvermont is like Conroe in that it provides that same foundation. _____ It is a START.

Topic.Title: Intc. New chips mobile and tablet

Message.Msg: Conroe was a start alright, it basically killed AMD as a serious x86 competitor and took its stock price from $42 to $2. Silvermont might precipitate a similar fall in ARMH's stock price.

Topic.Title: Intc. New chips mobile and tablet

Message.Msg: OoO helps. Wonder why it didn't happen sooner.

Topic.Title: Intc. New chips mobile and tablet

Message.Msg: OoO costs power especially in x86, it probably took 22nm trigate transistors to fully minimize this. Intel also took too long converting 1st generation 45nm Atom into a 32nm SoC, 4 years !, which held up the micro-architectural pipeline.
